title-group.article-title: Activation–retardation in sol–gel reactions for additive manufacturing of transparent poly(methylsilsesquioxane) aerogels

contrib-group.aff: https://ror.org/035psfh38grid.255169.c0000 0000 9141 4786State Key Laboratory of Advanced Fiber Materials, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Donghua University, Shanghai, China

abstract.p: Coupling superior thermal insulation performance with high transparency for solar transmission and excellent processability in aerogels is a challenging yet promising subject. Here, we report a direct ink writing strategy to create transparent polymethylsilsesquioxane (PMSQ) aerogels from gel inks with desired rheology, by merely using acid-base dual modulators to achieve “activation–retardation” of polycondensation reaction. The printed aerogels are pure PMSQ, have a transmittance of 97% in the visible-near infrared range, thermal conductivity (16.2 mW m−1 K−1) lower than that of still air, and low density (0.08 g cm−3). We demonstrate new possibilities of our 3D-printed transparent aerogels, such as device encapsulation for heat insulation and cylindrical cooling shields for lighting.

Authors report a direct ink writing strategy to create transparent polymethylsilsesquioxane aerogels from gel inks with desired rheology, using acid-base dual modulators to achieve “activation–retardation” of polycondensation reaction.

funding-source.institution: This work was supported by the National Key Research and Development Program of China (2021YFB3701600, Y.C.), the National Science Foundation of China (52273031, Y.C.), the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (2232024Y-01 and 2232025G-07, Y.C.), “DHU” Distinguished Young Professor Program (LZA2024001, Y.C.) and State Key Laboratory for Modification of Chemical Fibers and Polymer Materials, Donghua University.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Energy-saving materials for light and thermal management have been a prevailing research topic from the perspective of sustainable development. Lightweight silica aerogels are a kind of fascinating candidate owing to their ultralow thermal conductivity (λ < 20 mW m−1 K−1)1,2, inherent low solar absorption in the Vis-NIR solar region and comparable refractive index to air (<1.1)3. Previous studies reveal that the optical transparency and thermal insulation properties of silica aerogels could be achieved by controlling Vis-NIR transmission in the solar spectrum, mid-infrared thermal radiation, and minimizing heat transfer through conduction and convection (Fig. 1)4–8. On the molecular scale, surface hydroxyl groups (-OH) and the absorbed water contribute a strong and broad absorbance band near 1200 nm, 1400 nm, and 1900 nm, which should be eliminated to allow more NIR passing through silica aerogels. The hydrophobic nature of the aerogel is important for maintaining thermal–insulation property if the material is exposed to high humid environments (i.e., rain, snow, etc.). In addition, the inherent high extinction character in the mid-IR range (8–14 μm) of silica aerogels ensures low radiative conductivity, minimizing radiative transfer between interior and exterior (Note S1) On the nano- and micro-scale, the size of interconnected particle nanostructure (small particles along with a network of pores) should be sufficient smaller than the wavelength of visible light (380–780 nm), and internal microstructure inhomogeneity should be avoided (Note S2)4,9–11. Such small particle nanostructure is also beneficial to reduce the solid phase and gas phase heat transfer5,12. To a certain extent, the above criteria can be achieved by modifying the sol–gel chemistry for silica aerogels preparation9,12–16. In particular, an acid–base two-step approach accompanied with a surfactant-assisted strategy has been demonstrated to successfully control the pore size, particle size, and structure homogeneity of the silica aerogel, which may provide high-quality microstructure to construct transparent aerogels.Fig. 1Working principles of transparent silica aerogel as energy-saving materials.
The high Vis-NIR transparency and superior insulating properties originate from the aerogel’s sufficiently small particle and pore sizes as well as uniform skeleton microstructure. DPore and DParticle represent the diameters of pores and particles, respectively.

Besides the solar transmittance and thermal conductivity, machinability is another key in designing silica aerogels for light and thermal management. Silica is one of covalently bonded inorganic materials that could be obtained through hydrolysis and polycondensation reaction. However, owing to the brittleness and fragility, silica aerogels are impossible to subtractive manufacturing analogous to ubiquitous polymeric materials in modern society that possess various properties and ease of processing17,18. Surprisingly, the polymer-like rheological property allows the silica gel inks to be readily processed into objects with structural complexity and variable architectures. The viable option reported recently for manufacturing silica aerogel is additive manufacturing (3D printing), a process that needs inks with excellent printing rheology, the ability to solidify after printing, and highly porous structure for ultralow thermal conductivity after drying19,20. To meet above requirements, polymers or acrylate-modified silica sols were usually used in the inks, these polymer compositions were retained in the final aerogel products, and resulting in relatively poor shape fidelity or limited thermal insulation21,22. Very recently, a breakthrough material of pure silica aerogel was developed by using slurry of silica aerogel powder (diameter of powder particles: 10 µm) suspended in a dilute silica nanoparticle sol (diameter of sol particles: 10 nm)23. After printing, an ammonia-vapor-induced gelation was followed. However, the obtained silica aerogels had opaque appearance due to uneven particle sizes. In addition, processes involving an ammonia atmosphere resulted in uncontrolled polycondensation reactions and prevented high-throughput manufacturing. The already difficult task of designing transparent insulating silica aerogels is made even more difficult by the inherent requirements of 3D printing.

To overcome these challenges, we exploit the polymer chemistry of PMSQ to demonstrate the 3D printing of PMSQ aerogels with controlled microstructure. An activation–retardation strategy was proposed to control the polycondensation process of sol, achieving superior processibility of the aerogels with high transparency and excellent thermal insulation properties. Methyltrimethoxysilane (MTMS) bearing -CH3 groups was deliberately selected as the precursor because the resulting PMSQ is inherently hydrophobic. Hydrolysis and polycondensation reactions are sequentially carried out in acetic acid/urea/surfactant (cetyl-trimethyl-ammonium chloride, CTAC) aqueous solution. Specifically, acetic acid and urea as dual modulators achieve “activation–retardation” of polycondensation reactions for precisely regulating the rheology of this system. Notably, acetic acid is a small acidic molecule that can volatilize at ambient temperature, while urea could be thermally hydrolyzed into carbon dioxide and ammonia (basic). Highly acidic conditions (pH <4) strongly promote hydrolysis of silane; while basic conditions “activate” polycondensation process13,14. Once polycondensation proceeds, the reaction process could be “retarded” by additional acetic acid, the obtained gel inks with desired printing rheology could be kinetically stabilized accordingly. Besides increasing the viscosity of the ink, the addition of CTAC also prevents solid-liquid phase separation to improve its uniformity during the sol–gel process, and ensures the generation of small-sized PMSQ nanoparticles14,16. The as-expected solidification of the 3D-printed PMSQ gel object is achieved by the newly generated water-soluble ammonia from urea decomposition at an elevated temperature. The acid–base dual pH modulators confer precise control of sol–gel process, and CTAC combines the effect of phase-separation inhibitor and rheological property regulator to ensure nanoscale structure formation. These jointly contribute to the final aerogels with excellent processibility as well as optimized optical and thermal insulation properties. We demonstrate the 3D printing of transparent PMSQ aerogels (Vis-NIR transmission: up to 97%, thermal conductivity: 16.2 mW m−1 K−1, density: 0.08 g cm−3, specific surface aera: 778 m2 g−1, pore sizes: 23 nm, particle size: 5 nm), which can be applied to device encapsulation for heat insulation and cooling shields for lighting.

sec.title: Inks preparation with printable rheology by regulating polycondensation reaction
sec.p:
In our approach, the process from monomer precursor to crosslinked gel and printed structure can be roughly separated into four stages (Fig. 2a). MTMS is firstly hydrolyzed at the acid conditions (pH = ~4, stage 1), the hydrolyzed oligomeric fluid is then turned into a loosely-crosslinked polymethylsilsesquioxane (PMSQ) gel network when the pH is shifted to basic side by raising solution temperature at 60 °C (pH = 6.5–7, stage 2) (Figure S1). With continuously increasing ammonia concentration (pH > 7, stage 3i), the further polycondensation reaction results in dense PMSQ gel network (at the molecular level), which could not be printed due to a dramatic rise in viscosity. Instead, if the solution pH decreases back to acidic condition (pH = ~4, stage 3ii) by using acetic acid, the polycondensation reaction is retarded and the loose PMSQ gel network is retained (Figure S2, S3). Such loose PMSQ gels with desired printing rheology as the inks are ready for direct 3D printing (pH = ~4, stage 4). The inks are automatically deposited onto a moving x-y stage to produce 2D patterns, following by the repeated increment at the z-direction to creat the desired 3D structure (Fig. 2b; and Supplementary Movie 1). After the aging process at the elevated temperature (60 °C), the gel (pH = ~6) with filamentary architecture is retained and solidified (Fig. 2c; and Figure S3). Following by a supercritical drying, the PMSQ aerogel is obtained. The optical image and the corresponding laser profilometry scan were acquired for the obtained aerogel (Fig. 2d, e), showing a translucent 3D periodic structure composed of top and bottom layers of aerogel filament assemblies. The excellent height uniformity and large span indicate the good shape fidelity of the PMSQ aerogel during drying process. Printed aerogels with high transparency (Fig. 2f) are expected to be used as advanced window products (e.g., energy-efficient windows and glass skylight) to boost the efficiency of existing windows in cold regions (Fig. 2g), as we demonstrated using 3D printed transparent PMSQ aerogels (TPAs) in a pyramid shape to prototype an architectural skylight (Fig. 2h). We believe that PMSQ aerogels with both high transparency and high thermal insulation properties, will advance their practice in energy-saving and carbon-reducing design.Fig. 23D printing of transparent aerogels by direct ink writing.
a Schematic illustration of the preparation and writing process of gel inks to produce polymethylsilsesquioxane (PMSQ) aerogels. Stage 1: Methyltrimethoxysilane (MTMS) is hydrolyzed under acid conditions (pH = ~4) to generate oligomeric products (less branched siloxane networks), resulting in the formation of nanoclusters. Stage 2: In the presence of ammonia (pH = 6.5–7), the alkaline solutions accelerate the polycondensation reaction of sol to form a continuous three-dimensional network. Stage 3: Gel inks with desired rheology obtained by retarding the polycondensation reaction with additional acid. Stage 4: The gel ink is printed through a nozzle, followed by an aging process at 60 °C to further solidify the gel, and finally the aerogel is obtained by supercritical drying. b Photographs of 3D printing periodic lattice from gel inks and c) the resulted printed architecture after aging process. b, e Optical micrographs of transparent PMSQ aerogels (TPAs) assembled from extruded filaments that retain their cylindrical shape after drying (d), with corresponding profilometry scans of their top surfaces (e). f Photograph of a clear lightweight TPA sample (bulk density of 0.08 g cm-3) on leaves. g, h Schematic (planer shape) and photograph (pyramid shape) of TPAs as a skylight for energy-saving buildings. Source data are provided as a Source Data file.

To fabricate the printable gel inks, the control of a transition from sol to gel state is key. In an acidic solution, hydrolysis leads to the generation of oligomeric products and the formation of nanoclusters24. When the solution pH is shifted to basic side by elevating the solution temperature (designated as t = 0 min in Fig. 3a), the polycondensation reactions accelerate, and then the crosslinking is occurred among the sol nanoparticles. This initially causes the nanoparticles to aggregate into larger assemblies, and a continuous three-dimensional network is finally generated24,25. Fig. 3a shows the typical rheological behavior of the sol–gel process, that is, a plateau stage with aggregation of colloidal sol particles (denoted as α region), followed by a sudden increase in system viscosity to form a loosely crosslinked gel network (β region), and then the gel maturation regime with the formation of a densely crosslinked gel network (γ region). For the printable inks, a high viscosity is required to well maintain the printed shapes, but need to flow at yield stress through the nozzle26,27. Therefore, the printable viscosity should be stabilized at a critical point (indicated by a pentagram, ★) by inhibiting polycondensation reaction before the gel loses its fluidity.Fig. 3Rheological properties of the printable gel inks.
a Viscosity changes revealing three regions of common sol–gel process: α) a plateau stage with nanoclusters aggregation, β) an abrupt increase in the viscosity of the system with the gel network formation, γ) a gel maturation process associated with the formation of a densely crosslinked gel network. Inset: Aggregation-induced emission (AIE) molecules of TPE-Sulfonate serve as “built-in” sensors that can visualize changes in the microenvironment of the gel network, based on changes in fluorescence emission intensity (Figure S2). b Green line: viscosity changes of common sol–gel process. Red line: viscosity stabilization by adding acetic acid as a retardant at the critical point. c A series of printable gel inks with different viscosities obtained by controlling the acetic acid addition time. Inkjet printability window defined by the viscosities. Different markers represent different system viscosities, depending on when acetic acid is added. Several identical markers appearing at the same time represent an error bar. (n = 10 independent samples, mean ± SD). d, e Shelf life of polymethylsilsesquioxane (PMSQ) gel ink: apparent viscosity at different applied shear rates (d), and storage (G’) and loss (G”) modulus versus applied shear stress (e), for fresh gel ink (blue dots) and after 7 days of storage (red dots, 25 °C, 40% relative humidity).f The thixotropic tests by alternative varying the shear rates. Source data are provided as a Source Data file.

The retardation effect of polycondensation reaction with acetic acid was studied by the viscosity variation (Fig. 3b). When the sol–gel system reached the critical point without further addition of acetic acid, the solution viscosity increased quickly until the system could no longer flowed. By contrast, by addition of acetic acid as an inhibitor at the critical point (★), the solution viscosity increased slightly and remained steady. The viscosity confirms that moving the solution pH back to acidic side (pH = ~4) by adding acetic acid could effectively inhibited the polycondensation reaction. Taking advantage of the “retardation effect” in the polycondensation reaction, the rheology of the PMSQ gel could be adjusted by controlling the timing of acetic acid addition: earlier addition of acetic acid for lower viscosity; later addition of acetic acid to enable higher viscosity (Fig. 3c). The ink’s adjustable rheology can be adapted to a variety of applications. Lower viscosity enables filaments to coalesce into a continuous bulk material without voids, while higher viscosity favors long-span open structure for printing complex geometric objects (e.g., 15 mm for a 600 μm diameter filament) (Figure S4).

The desired gel inks exhibit shear thinning behavior through the nozzles required for the printing process (Fig. 3d, e; and Figure S5a), with the viscosity recovering quickly in the absence of shear and the extruded filaments retaining their shape after printing. Such thixotropic properties of the gel inks were studied by the measurement of cyclic step shear rate (Fig. 3f). The results show that the viscosity of the gel inks decreased rapidly when high shear rates (100 s−1) were applied, but recovered rapidly when the shear rates returned to low levels (0.01 s−1). Moreover, the ink has a shelf life of one week (Fig. 3d, e and Figure S6). As shown in Fig. 3e and Figure S5b, the storage modulus (G’) and loss modulus (G”) are used to characterize the elasticity and viscous properties of gel inks, respectively, through dynamic rheological measurements in a strain scanning mode. When the storage modulus is greater than the loss modulus (G’ > G”) before the yield point (G’ = G”) at small oscillation strains, the ink displays a solid-state behavior and can maintain the printed shape after nozzle extrusion. After reaching the yield point under a large oscillation strain (G’ < G”), the ink is closer to a liquid state, ensuring smooth flow under a driving force during the printing process26–28. With these characteristics, objects can be printed at a resolution of 160 μm (Figure S7). Thereafter, the loosely-crosslinked network in the printed gel object is activated due to the generated ammonia at the elevated temperature, and undergoes further polycondensation reactions, thereby forming a densely-crosslinked gel object.

In this system, besides precise control of solution pH to control degree of crosslinking, CTAC surfactant also plays an important role during preparing printable gel ink (Note S3 and Table S1). (i) Phase separation suppression: During the polycondensation process of sol, weak hydrophobic interactions between methyl groups of sol and the alkyl chains of the CTAC suppress phase separation and ensuring uniform microstructure13,14. (ii) Rheological properties regulation: CTAC can regulate the ink formulas suitable for 3D printing technologies with high requirements on rheological properties. The addition of CTAC could increase the viscosity and modulus of gel inks, ensuring good shape retention of extruded filaments29. However, excessive CTAC would inhibit the interaction of gel networks, resulting in the lower crosslinking density, and therefore a collapsed printed gel structure will appear (Figure S8–S10; Supplementary Movie 2)13,30. Therefore, considering the two aspects above, the CTAC composition should be controlled within a certain range. We identified the amount of the surfactant could influence pore structures31,32, thereby optimizing the microstructure of PMSQ aerogels for obtaining aerogels with high transparency and high thermal insulation properties (Table S2).

sec.title: 3D-printed aerogel objects and their microstructure
sec.p:
After solvent exchange and supercritical CO2 drying, the internal solvent as well as the surfactants can be removed. The obtained objects comprise entirely of PMSQ aerogel, as proved by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) (Figure S11)33,34 and 29Si solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy (Figure S12)35. The water contact angle of the as-prepared aerogels is ~151° (Fig. 4a, b; Supplementary Movie 3). The inherent superhydrophobic property is attributed to the hydrophobic moieties (-CH3) throughout PMSQ structure35,36. Various aerogel objects filamentary architecture could be printed with high shape fidelity, precision, and transparency (Fig. 4c, d; and Figure S13). The printed filaments could retain a circular cross-section with a certain diameter (e.g., 925 μm), which are allowed to fuse together at their intersections (Fig. 4e, f). Each spanning filament displays a smooth outer surface and consists of a network of uniform mesoporous nanoparticles, as evidenced by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Fig. 4g, h; and Figure S14). The particle size of PMSQ nanoparticles is uniform and controlled at around 5 nm, which is observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (Fig. 4i, j; and Figure S15) The shape of the resulted PMSQ aerogel skeletons were further verified by small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS). After background subtraction, the scattering curve contains a mass fractal region because the slope of the fitted straight lines in the porod regime is –1.9, which is characteristic of typical PMSQ aerogels (Fig. 4k)10,37. Analysis was performed using SasView, a program that determines the shape of PMSQ nanoparticles based on the bell-shaped P(r) functions (Fig. 4k, inset)38, showing that the nanoparticles were globular. The specific surface aera and average pore sizes are 778 m2 g−1 and 23 nm, respectively (Fig. 4l, m; and Figure S16–S17). High thermal insulation property of the aerogels could be expected due to the highly porous structure and small pore size that smaller than the mean free path of gas molecules (~70 nm). In addition, PMSQ itself has extremely low absorption of visible light. The incident light would be preserved to the maximum due to the nanostructure of the PMSQ aerogel. Such mesoporous structure will facilitate PMSQ aerogels to have both high transparency and high thermal insulation properties, which will advance their practice in the field of energy-saving materials39–41.Fig. 43D printed transparent polymethylsilsesquioxane (PMSQ) aerogel objects (TPAs), their morphology and microstructure, and selected properties.
a, b Hydrophobic properties of TPAs (a) and the water contact angle of the TPAs (b). The inset shows that the surface of TPAs contains many hydrophobic groups (e.g., CH3). c, d) 3D printed transparent PMSQ aerogels with various shapes and patterns. e–h Scanning electron micrographs of printed TPAs acquired at different magnifications. Filaments maintain their cylindrical shape after printing and supercritical drying, as shown in the cross-sectional image e) and their magnification image (f) showing the filaments coalesce easily with adjacent layers for good layer adhesion. (n = 5 independent samples). g The smooth exterior surfaces and the circle interface between two filaments. (n = 5 independent samples). h Highest magnification image showing a porous structure composed of interconnected spherical nanoparticles. (n = 5 independent samples). i Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) of printed TPAs. Nanoscale granular skeletons are marked with red circles or parallel lines. (n = 3 independent samples). j The particle size statistical distribution column and its normal distribution curve obtained from the TEM image. k SAXS spectrograms of TPAs. Inset showing the distance distribution function generated from the software SasView. (“r” represents the distance between two points within a particle or material. This usually refers to the distance from one scattering center to another. “P(r)” is Pair Distance Distribution Function, which is used to describe the probability distribution of the distance between two points in the same sample.) l, m Nitrogen-sorption isotherms of TPAs and the corresponding pore size distribution plot from nitrogen adsorption branch by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) analysis. Source data are provided as a Source Data file.

sec.title: Optical and thermal properties of transparent PMSQ aerogels
sec.p:
We show that the aerogel features very high visible-range transmissivity (within 98%–95%) for various thicknesses (1.7–4.3 mm) of the aerogels (Fig. 5a, b), which is much higher than ~90% of commercial borosilicate glass (Figure S18). Besides the high transparency in visible range, the excellent transmission in NIR band is also displayed (Fig. 5c). Compared with that of the traditional hydrophilic silica aerogels42,43, the high NIR transparency of our PMSQ aerogels is attributed to a large number of hydrophobic methyl groups on the surface of PMSQ aerogel, blocking the environmental moisture to be absorbed in the aerogel network. Meanwhile, the PMSQ aerogels are opaque in mid-IR range (8–14 μm) (Fig. 5c), which is desirable for the reduction of the radiative heat transfer, providing the thermal barrier properties to minimize the radiative thermal conductivity of PMSQ aerogels40,44.Fig. 5Excellent optical properties and thermal insulation performance of 3D printed transparent PMSQ aerogels (TPAs) for thermal management in different application fields.
Spectral transmittance in visible range for a 1.7 mm-thick slab shown in the inset (highlighted with dashed lines) (a) and TPAs slabs of different thicknesses (b). The inset in Fig. 5a uses the logo of Donghua University as the background. Authorization has been obtained from the university. The inset in Fig. 5b showing the transmittance as a function of TPAs thickness. (n = 3 independent samples, mean ± SD). c Transmittance spectra of 1.7 mm-thick aerogel slab in the solar and infrared regions. d Thickness dependence of optical transmittance of aerogels with different pore sizes in the visible (top panel) and NIR regions (bottom panel). e A 650 nm laser beam passing through 3.5 mm-TPAs without deviation. f Photo images showing the laser spot and laser intensity that transmitted through the air and TPAs, respectively. g, h Schematic drawings (g) and a photo image (h) of transparent polymethylsilsesquioxane (PMSQ) aerogels as an insulating cap for electronic components protection. i Temperature evolution of the electronic components with (blue line) and without (red line) aerogel protection. j Schematic drawings of transparent PMSQ aerogels as lampshades with light weight and thermal insulation characteristics for improving indoor plants growth. k Optical (left panel) and infrared images (right panel) of the lamp bulb wrapped with different lampshades (bare lamp, aerogel, PMMA, cotton). Source data are provided as a Source Data file.

The aerogels are almost transparent in the Vis-NIR range. The transparency of the aerogels is determined by the geometrical characteristics and the refractive index of the scattering centers (small particles and a network of pores)45. For the highly porous aerogels, we found that the increased pore size reduced this transparency significantly. According to Rayleigh-Gans theory, these large-sized pores act as Rayleigh centers to strongly scatter visible light, resulting in poor light transmittance of aerogel (Fig. 5d, top panel)4,10,11. However, the pore size of aerogels has little effect on the NIR transparency, because NIR transparency is merely related to the inherent chemical structure of TPAs (Fig. 5d, bottom panel)46,47. For the transparent aerogels with sufficient small pore and particle size, the transmitted sunlight throughout the visible and NIR wavelengths is benefit for sustaining the human’s daily life, especially in cold climate regions. For such transparent aerogels, the high air constitution and low solid content (~6% by volume) account for a low refractive index contrast between the homogenous aerogel skeleton and the air medium. Such refractive index-matching property of aerogel and air could be indicated by the negligible deflection angles of incident 650-nm red laser at the aerogel-air interfaces according to Snell’s law (Fig. 5e; Supplementary Movie 4). The intensity of the laser light penetrating the TPAs was detected. Figure 5f shows the energy loss of the red laser propagating in air and aerogel media, respectively. It is found that the intensity exerted little change (5%, from 196 to 186 W m−2) (Figure S19) when a laser beam traveled through the aerogel, the laser light is almost unperturbed, further indicating the low light-scattering of our aerogels.

While ensuring maximum visible light transmission, TPAs also serve as excellent thermal barriers, benefiting from their outstanding thermal insulation properties. The nanostructure of TPAs ensures low thermal conductivity (λ: 16. 2 mW m−1 K−1, Figure S20 and Note S4), where small pores (less than the mean free path of air molecules) restrict the collisions of air molecules, while particles network with low bulk density minimize the thermal conduction through the solid networks (~6% by volume, λ ∝ ρ1.5, Table S2, Figure S21)48. Here, the pores of our TPAs are too small for convection to occur. Therefore, gas and solid frameworks conduction mainly constitute the overall thermal conductivity of TPAs (Figure S22, S23 and Note S1). In addition, TPAs also inhibit radiation heat transfer because of low thermal-range transmission, further boosting the thermal insulation performance. Besides optical and thermal properties described above, the temperature resistance of materials themselves is required. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and derivative thermogravimetric (DTG) measurements show that TPAs are thermally stable at both ambient and elevated temperatures (< 350 °C) (Figure S24).

To illustrate the utility of TPAs in tailored scenarios, we demonstrate the printed aerogel as an insulator cap that can prevent damage to thermally sensitive components (Fig. 5g, h; and Figure S25). The local temperature of a capacitor exposed to contact heat is only 48 °C with printed aerogel cap, compared to 80 °C without protection (Fig. 5i). Besides, all plants need light for photosynthesis, the process of converting light into chemical energy needed for plant growth49. To alleviate the pressure of food shortage, the closed growing system of the plant factory can realize uninterrupted production of vegetables all year around, and the production speed is about two to four times faster than traditional planting50,51. In the plant factories, facilities utilize artificial control of light, temperature, moisture, and carbon dioxide levels51. However, grow lights emit a lot of heat, and too much heat can burn the plants. To address above problem, the cylindrical lampshade was demonstrated as thermal barrier to wrap around lamp bulb (Fig. 5j). The printed TPAs, commercial poly (methyl methacrylate) (PMMA), and cotton were engineered into the same architecture (wall thickness: 3 mm) for comparison (Figure S26). The printed TPAs-based lampshade shows similar transparency with that of PMMA (a commercial glass substitute). Figure 5k shows the heat from the lamp could be isolated at the source and only light could be transmitted, illustrating the thermal barrier performance of TPAs-based lampshade. The results indicate that the printed TPAs insulators could prevent irradiated plants from overheating (e.g., ideal growth temperatures for tomato are 21–29 °C), that is, high temperatures should be avoided50,52. TPAs are transparent in the Vis-NIR wavelength range, that is, Vis-NIR light produced by the bulb can pass through our transparent lampshade to sustain plant growth and development. It is noted that the effects of UV light on photomorphogenesis, stress responses, and secondary metabolite production play a crucial role in plant growth and development. Our aerogels exhibit high spectral transmittance in the UV part, in particular the 1.7 mm-thick aerogel slab has a transmittance of up to 94% in the UV-A and UV-B parts (Figure S27). Besides, key opportunities of TPAs may include situations where light should be transmitted, yet the local temperature gradient need to be restricted, and architecture is also complicated simultaneously, such as invasive thermal therapy, electronic display devices, and optical devices.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The value of our work lies in the “activation-retardation” process in sol-gel reactions, and the viscosity of the obtained gel ink is adjustable and can remain stable under ambient conditions. It provides the possibility not only for 3D printing aerogels but also for mold processing aerogels. To demonstrate the superiority of our gel inks, we chose a 3D printing technology that has high requirements on gel rheology. More than that, 3D printing can also create aerogels with complex geometries in a simple and controllable one-step process. In addition to the aerogel insulator cap and aerogel cylindrical lampshade that shown in Fig. 5g–k, which generally require high-viscosity inks, low-viscosity could also be used to print ordinary aerogel slabs. The excellent thermal barrier performance of the TPAs slabs with different sizes and thickness on top of hot plates (100 °C, left panel) and cold plates (−20 °C, right panel) are demonstrated (Figure S28). The surface temperatures of TPAs are directly relative to the thickness of the printed aerogel slabs. The aerogel slabs obtained through 3D printing enable flexible switching of processing dimensions and avoid structural damage caused by demolding during the traditional molding process. Therefore, 3D printing technology provides a new paradigm for the preparation of silica aerogels. In the following sections, we also demonstrate the feasibility of printing aerogel slabs and demonstrate their potential applications in energy-saving glazing and solar collectors. TPAs slabs serve as excellent thermal barriers, and can be used as panes within multi-layer insulated glass units, capable of boosting the window’s thermal insulation performance and reducing energy consumption (Figure S29–S34 and Note S5). Another application involves using TPAs slabs as a solar thermal collector. Efficient use of solar heat helps reduce energy bills and lower the carbon footprint (Figure S35–S37, and Note S6). Our TPAs combine high transparency and high thermal insulation properties to achieve energy savings and demonstrate their potential for insulating glazing and solar thermal energy utilization.

In summary, by using pH-regulated polycondensation to control the sol–gel process of sol, the resulting gel inks with desired rheology enable them to be readily processed into aerogel objects with structural complexity and shape fidelity, notably small particle and pore size as well as high mesoporosity. With these unique internal microstructures, the PMSQ aerogel objects show up to 97% Vis-NIR transmission, high extinction character in mid-IR range, and ultralow thermal conductivity of 16.2 mW m−1 K−1, making the aerogels ideal for energy-saving materials. In addition, the inherent superhydrophobicity of PMSQ aerogel makes it durable, coming from the abundant methyl groups on its skeleton. Moreover, 3D printing process avoids subtractive manufacturing problems and helps to design aerogels into any shapes and sizes to compatible with new applications. For example, our transparent aerogels can be made into cylindrical caps for electronic components protection. Furthermore, light cooling shields are also demonstrated to keep irradiated plants from overheating in plant factory. New fields of applications also include but not limited to invasive thermal therapy, electronic display devices, and optical devices.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Methyltrimethoxysilane (MTMS, Analytical Reagent (AR)) and cetyltrimethylammonium chloride (CTAC, Chemical Purity (CP)) were supplied by the Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd (Shanghai, China). Acetic acid (AR) was purchased from Aladdin (Shanghai, China). Urea (AR), isopropanol (AR) and fluorescein sodium were obtained from the Shanghai Titan Scientific Co. Ltd (Shanghai, China). Graphite oxide (GO) nanosheets (1 wt%) aqueous dispersion was supplied by ShenZhen Matterene Tech. Co. Ltd., China. All the chemicals and solvents were used as received.

sec.title: Inks formulation
sec.p: First, 5.0 mL of MTMS, 0.8 g of CTAC, and 5.0 g of urea were added to 15.0 mL of acetic acid aqueous solution (10.0 mmol L−1) at the same time, and stirred at ambient temperature for 30 min to obtain a clear and transparent sol solution. The obtained sol was transferred to a sealed container and then placed in a 60 °C oven for the required time (3–4 h) to perform the polycondensation process. Afterward, a certain amount of acetic acid was quickly added under vigorous stirring at ambient temperature to obtain the gel inks. Next, the gel inks were transferred to the bucket of the 3D printing system for direct writing.

sec.title: 3D printing of transparent PMSQ aerogels
sec.p: Additive manufacturing of aerogel materials was performed on a commercial pressure-controlled direct ink 3D printing system (BS4.2, GESIM). The mechanically driven extrusion process with optimized parameters used a micronozzle with an inner diameter of 600 μm, an extrusion speed of 6 mm s−1, an extrusion pressure of 20–50 kPa, and a layer spacing of 0.7–0.8 mm. The printing path was controlled by an external computer control system in conjunction with the operating software (GesimRobotics). All 3D printed objects were printed on plastic sheets at ambient temperature, which were then transferred to a sealed container at 60 °C and left for 10–12 hours to complete the gelling and aging processes. The aged 3D printed objects were soaked in distilled water to remove residual surfactant and chemicals. Finally, the objects were exchanged into isopropanol and then liquid CO2 for supercritical drying (40 °C, 9 MPa) to directly obtain 3D-printed transparent aerogels.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: Morphological Structures: The chemical structure of MTMS, sol, PMSQ gel inks and TPAs were studied using liquid-state (in D2O) and solid-state 29Si NMR spectroscopy, recorded on a Bruker AVANCE III 600 MHz and 400 MHz spectrometer, respectively. The absence of CTAC surfactants in TPAs was confirmed by using ATR-FTIR (Nicolet 6700). The morphology and microstructure of TPAs were observed by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi SU8010) and ultra-depth-of-field microscopy (DVM6, Leica, Germany). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, specific surface area and pore size distribution of the aerogels were characterized by an Automatic Surface Area and Porosity Analyzer (Autosorb-iQ, Quantachrome, USA). Before measurements, the samples were degassed under high vacuum (< 0.01 mbar) at 150 °C for 5 h. Small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) measurements were performed on a Xeuss 2.0 (Xenocs, France) to determine the scattering length distribution. First, we used a Xeuss 2.0 (Xenocs, France) to obtain the SAXS curve (I ~ q). Then we inserted the SAXS data into SasView, a program that determines the shape of PMSQ nanoparticles based on the bell-shaped P(r) functions (data processing process: lode data; Send data to; Inversion; P(r)~r curve).

Rheological Properties: Rheological characterizations of all gel inks were performed on a rotational rheometer (MCR302, Anton Paar) with a plate geometry of 50 mm, a gap height of 0.5 mm, and a temperature of 25 °C. In situ monitoring the sol–gel process was investigated through time sweep tests at 60 °C, 1% constant strain, and 1 Hz constant frequency. Steady-state flow experiments were performed with shear rate sweeps ranging from 10−1 to 102 s−1 to record the apparent viscosity at different shear rates. Oscillation experiments with stress sweeps from 10−1 to 103 Pa were performed at a constant frequency of 1 Hz to record the storage and loss moduli as a function of shear stress. The shelf-life of gel inks was checked after 7 days of storage at 25 °C, 40% relative humidity, and apparent viscosity and modulus were tested and compared with fresh gel inks. Thixotropic testing was performed by alternating the shear rate at a constant frequency of 1 Hz.

Optical properties: The direct-hemispherical transmittance spectra were measured using a UV-Vis-NIR spectrophotometer (UV3600, Shimadzu, Japan) with an integrating sphere. All the optical pictures were taken using a Canon digital camera.

Thermal Insulation Properties: Thermal conductivity of TPAs, PMMA and glass was measured with a steady-state heat flow meter (TA FOX 200) in air at 25 °C. Thermal conductivity of PMSQ aerogel powder was measured by a transient planar source thermal conductivity analyzer (Hot Disk TPS2500S) in air at 25 °C. All infrared thermal images were taken by an Infrared thermal imaging camera (Fotric 347 + -L25), and the temperatures were recorded in real time. Cold plate (Wuhan Chongguang Technology Co.Ltd) provide the low enviroment of tests.

Other properties: The water contact angle was measured at ambient temperature using an optical contact angle meter (Biolin Scientific, Theta Flex, Sweden) with a water droplet volume of 3 μL. The pH value during the sol–gel process was monitored using a pH meter (Mettler Toledo, FE28-Standard). A standard solar simulator (Oriel Newport 69911) provided a solar illumination environment, and an optical power meter (SM206-solar, Xinbao) was used to monitor the light intensity. The thermal stability analysis was performed with a TGA thermal analyzer (Libra/209F1, Netzsch, Germany) from 30 °C to 900 °C in air at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1.

sec.title: Reporting summary
sec.p: Further information on research design is available in the Nature Portfolio Reporting Summary linked to this article.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: Y.C. and M.Z. conceived the project. M.G. performed the experiments. M.G., J.Zhang, C.X., X.Y., L.C., J.Zheng, W.Z., X.Z., Y.C. and M.Z. performed data analysis and participated in the discussion. M.G. and Y.C. contributed to the writing of this manuscript. All authors commented on, discussed, and approved the final version of the manuscript.

sec.title: Peer review information
sec.p: Nature Communications thanks the anonymous reviewer(s) for their contribution to the peer review of this work. A peer review file is available.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: All data are available within the main text, the Supplementary Information file, and the Source Data files. Source data are provided with this paper.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: A patent (CN202311644878.4) for gel inks and 3D printing transparent aerogel has been applied on behalf of Donghua University. Y.C., M.G., M.Z., J.Z., C.X., X.Y., L.C. and W.Z.are listed as inventors. The authors declare no other competing interests.
